dict.string: What is nature's fundamental algorithm?
Move towards pain, move away from pleasure
Move towards pleasure, move away from pain
Move towards pleasure 80%, move towards pain 20%
Move towards pleasure 50%, move towards pain 50%
Which of the following is an example of a person choosing pain over pleasure?
Masochism
Working on Friday night instead of partying, in order to save money for a holiday
Studying on Friday night instead of going out with friends, in order to get good grades
There is no such example: we can only ever choose pleasure over pain
What is the difference between humans and animals when it comes to choosing pleasure over pain?
Humans can aim at a pleasure they envision in the future; animals cannot
Animals can aim at a pleasure they envision in the future; humans cannot
There is absolutely no difference
Humans can choose pain over pleasure; animals cannot
Although humans can aim at a remote pleasure, whereas animals cannot, is there fundamentally still a difference between humans and animals in relation to chasing pleasures?
No. Fundamentally, both humans & animals are pulled toward whatever appears most pleasurable to them
No. Fundamentally, both humans & animals are nothing but mammals
Yes. The fact that humans can aim at a remote pleasure & animals cannot is the fundamental difference
Yes. In addition, humans can choose pain over pleasure, whereas animals cannot
What role does society play in the type of pleasure a person wants?
Society plays no role whatsoever in determining the type of pleasure a person wants
Society determines the type of pleasure a person wants
Society plays a minimal role in determining the type of pleasure a person wants
Society determines certain types of pleasure a person wants, but the person individually determines most of them
How many factors determine every organism's emergence and development?
1 factor
2 factors
3 factors
4 factors
Which of the following is the correct order of the 4 factors by which organisms emerge and develop?
Source » Source's Development » External Factors Directly Related to the Source » External Factors Not Related Directly to the Source
Source » External Factors Directly Related to the Source » External Factors Not Related Directly to the Source » Source's Development
External Factors Directly Related to the Source » Source » Source's Development » External Factors Not Related Directly to the Source
External Factors Not Related Directly to the Source » Source » Source's Development » External Factors Directly Related to the Source
Take, for example, a stalk of wheat that has rotted in the ground and arrived at a state of sowing many stalks of wheat. Which of the following is an example of its first factor, the wheat's source?
The cause & effect growth of the wheat stalk
The minerals and the materials in the ground, the rain and the sun
The many stalks of wheat that have been sown
The wheat that has rotted in the ground

Using the same example of a stalk of wheat that has rotted in the ground and arrived at a state of sowing many stalks of wheat. Which of the following is an example of its second factor, the source's development?
The cause & effect growth of the wheat stalk
The minerals and the materials in the ground, the rain and the sun
The many stalks of wheat that have been sown
The wheat that has rotted in the ground
Again, using the same example. Which of the following is an example of its third factor, external factors directly related to the source?
The cause & effect growth of the wheat stalk
The minerals and the materials in the ground, the rain and the sun
The many stalks of wheat that have been sown
Hail or wind
For the last time, using the same example. Which of the following is an example of its fourth factor, external factors not related directly to the source?
The cause & effect growth of the wheat stalk
The minerals and the materials in the ground, the rain and the sun
The many stalks of wheat that have been sown
Hail or wind
